content:
🧬 Disease Module Discovery: Network Medicine for Drug Repurposing

Discover Disease Mechanisms and Drug Targets Through Network Analysis

Disease Module Discovery uses network medicine principles to identify connected subnetworks (modules) of disease-associated genes within the human protein-protein interaction network. By analyzing the local neighborhood of disease genes (seeds) in the interactome, this pipeline reveals molecular mechanisms, identifies novel disease genes, and prioritizes drug candidates for repurposing.

🎯 What is Network Medicine?

Network medicine recognizes that diseases rarely result from single gene abnormalities. Instead, diseases emerge from complex interactions among multiple genes and proteins. This pipeline:

  • 🔍 Identifies disease modules: Connected subnetworks enriched for disease-associated genes

  • 🧬 Discovers novel disease genes: Proteins that bridge known disease genes in the network

  • 💊 Prioritizes drug targets: Druggable proteins within or near disease modules

  • 🔄 Enables drug repurposing: Identifies existing drugs targeting disease module proteins

  • 📊 Validates findings: Comprehensive evaluation through functional enrichment and topology analysis

🔬 Multiple Algorithm Approach

The pipeline integrates six complementary algorithms for robust module identification:

Core Algorithms

  • 🎯 DOMINO: Active module identification using protein activity

    • Integrates expression data with network topology

    • Identifies modules with significant activity changes

    • Best for: Data-driven module discovery

  • 💎 DIAMOnD: DIseAse MOdule Detection algorithm

    • Iteratively expands from seed genes

    • Identifies proteins with significant connectivity to seeds

    • Best for: Seed-based module expansion

  • 🔧 ROBUST: Robust disease module miner

    • Identifies densely connected subnetworks

    • Optimizes for module robustness

    • Best for: Stable, high-confidence modules

  • ⚖️ ROBUST (bias-aware): Bias-corrected version

    • Accounts for node degree bias in networks

    • Reduces false positives from hub proteins

    • Best for: Unbiased module detection

  • 👥 1st Neighbors: Direct interaction partners

    • Simple but effective baseline method

    • Includes all immediate neighbors of seed genes

    • Best for: Conservative, literature-supported expansion

  • 🚶 Random Walk with Restart (RWR): Network diffusion

    • Simulates information flow through network

    • Identifies proteins in functional proximity to seeds

    • Best for: Capturing indirect functional relationships

Consensus benefits:

  • ✅ Robustness: Genes found by multiple methods are most reliable

  • ✅ Completeness: Different algorithms capture different aspects

  • ✅ Validation: Cross-method consistency increases confidence

🧪 Input Requirements

1. Seed Genes File (Required)

A file listing your disease-associated genes (seeds) - one gene per line:

# Example seeds.txt
TP53
BRCA1
BRCA2
PTEN
EGFR

Sources for seed genes:

  • 🧬 GWAS studies: Genome-wide association findings

  • 📊 Expression data: Differentially expressed genes

  • 🔬 Literature mining: Known disease genes from PubMed

  • 📚 Disease databases: OMIM, DisGeNET, ClinVar, GWAS Catalog

  • 🧮 Variant analysis: Genes with disease-causing mutations

Recommendations:

  • Use gene symbols (HGNC nomenclature) or Entrez IDs

  • Include 10-100 seed genes (too few = incomplete; too many = diluted signal)

  • Focus on high-confidence disease associations

  • Consider tissue/context specificity

2. Network File (Optional)

A tab-separated file defining protein-protein interactions:

# Example network.tsv
protein1  protein2  confidence
TP53      MDM2      0.95
TP53      CDK2      0.87
BRCA1     BRCA2     0.92

If not provided: Pipeline uses default human interactome from NeDRex database

Custom networks: Use for organism-specific or tissue-specific analyses

📊 Comprehensive Output & Evaluation

Disease Module Results

  • 🧬 Module gene lists: For each algorithm, genes included in disease module

  • 📊 Ranked candidates: Prioritized by connectivity and algorithm consensus

  • 🎯 Consensus modules: Genes identified by multiple methods (highest confidence)

  • 📈 Module overlap analysis: Venn diagrams showing algorithm agreement

Functional Analysis

  • 📚 Pathway enrichment (g:Profiler):

    • Gene Ontology biological processes

    • KEGG pathways

    • Reactome pathways

    • Disease associations (DisGeNET)

  • 🔍 Functional coherence (DIGEST):

    • Quantifies biological relevance of modules

    • Compares to random gene sets

    • Validates disease specificity

Network Topology Analysis

  • 📊 Module density: How tightly connected are module genes?

  • 🎯 Centrality metrics: Which genes are most important in the module?

  • 🌉 Bridging analysis: Genes connecting different disease aspects

  • 📈 Statistical significance: Module properties vs random expectation

Robustness Evaluation

  • 🔀 Seed permutation (optional, --run_seed_permutation):

    • Tests module stability to seed perturbations

    • Evaluates seed rediscovery capability

    • Identifies robust vs fragile predictions

  • 🔀 Network permutation (optional, --run_network_permutation):

    • Tests module stability across network variations

    • Assesses algorithm sensitivity to network topology

    • Validates findings aren't artifacts of specific network

Drug Repurposing Analysis

  • 💊 Drug prioritization (Drugst.One API):

    • Identifies FDA-approved drugs targeting module proteins

    • Ranks drugs by target coverage and relevance

    • Provides drug mechanisms and approval status

  • 🎯 Druggable target identification:

    • Highlights proteins with known drug interactions

    • Identifies novel repurposing opportunities

Visualization & Annotation

  • 🌐 Interactive network visualization (Drugst.One):

    • Web-based module exploration

    • Drug-target interaction overlays

    • Interactive filtering and analysis

  • 📊 Static network plots (graph-tool, pyvis):

    • Publication-ready module networks

    • Seed highlighting and module boundaries

    • HTML interactive views

  • 🏷️ Biological annotation (NeDRexDB):

    • Drug targeting information

    • Side effect profiles

    • Disease associations

    • Cellular localization

  • 📋 BioPAX export: Standardized format for further analysis

  • 📈 MultiQC report: Comprehensive summary of all results and evaluations

🩺 Applications & Use Cases

Drug Repurposing

Identify existing FDA-approved drugs that target proteins within disease modules. Success examples include aspirin for cardiovascular disease, metformin for aging, and thalidomide for cancer.

Target Discovery

Reveal novel drug targets by identifying central proteins in disease modules that lack current therapeutics. Prioritize targets based on druggability and network position.

Disease Mechanism Elucidation

Understand molecular pathways driving disease by analyzing functional enrichment of disease modules. Identify which biological processes are disrupted.

Biomarker Identification

Discover proteins that could serve as diagnostic or prognostic biomarkers based on their central position in disease modules.

Combination Therapy Design

Identify complementary drug targets within modules to design rational combination therapies that target multiple aspects of disease.

Precision Medicine

Stratify patients based on their specific disease module profiles to enable personalized treatment selection.

🏥 Disease Areas

Successfully applied to:

  • 🫀 Cardiovascular diseases: Heart failure, atherosclerosis, arrhythmias

  • 🧠 Neurological disorders: Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, ALS, epilepsy

  • 🎗️ Cancer: All cancer types, identifies oncogenic modules

  • 🦠 Infectious diseases: COVID-19, HIV, tuberculosis

  • ⚡ Metabolic disorders: Diabetes, obesity, metabolic syndrome

  • 🛡️ Autoimmune diseases: Rheumatoid arthritis, lupus, MS

  • 🫁 Respiratory diseases: Asthma, COPD, pulmonary fibrosis

  • 🧬 Rare diseases: Orphan diseases with limited treatment options

⚙️ Configuration Options

Module Inference

  • All algorithms enabled by default

  • Selectively disable: --skip_domino, --skip_diamond, --skip_robust, etc.

  • Tune parameters: Module size limits, significance thresholds

Evaluation Options

  • --run_seed_permutation: Enable seed robustness testing (time-intensive)

  • --run_network_permutation: Enable network robustness testing (time-intensive)

  • Default: Both disabled for faster runtime; enable for publications

Drug Prioritization

  • Automatic: Uses Drugst.One API for drug ranking

  • Filters: FDA-approved drugs, clinical trial drugs, experimental compounds

📈 Expected Runtime & Resources

  • ⏱️ Quick run (no permutations): 30-60 minutes

  • ⏱️ With seed permutation: 2-4 hours

  • ⏱️ With network permutation: 4-8 hours

  • 💻 Recommended: MEDIUM or LARGE node size

  • 💾 Storage: 1-5 GB depending on network size

🎓 Scientific Foundation

This pipeline is developed by the RePo4EU consortium, a European initiative for drug repurposing using network medicine. The methods are based on peer-reviewed algorithms:

  • DOMINO: Leisure et al., PLOS Computational Biology 2015

  • DIAMOnD: Ghiassian et al., PLOS Computational Biology 2015

  • ROBUST: Baumbach et al., Bioinformatics 2019

  • Network medicine framework: Barabási et al., Nature Reviews Genetics 2011
